repnme.cdata!: Malawi - Population and Family Planning Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that rapid
            increase in contraceptive prevalence is possible in rural
            Africa through Community Based distributors. The project
            proved the hypothesis by demonstrating dramatic increase in
            family planning uptake in rural Malawi through a district
            wide Community-based Distribution (CBD) program. The project
            was successful due to a balanced focus on both demand and
            supply issues. Demand was increased through a very effective
            multimedia Information, Education and Communication (IEC)
            campaign. Sustainability is an important concern CBD
            programs that requires special attention. Notwithstanding
            the fact that the cost per CYP in this project is much lower
            compared to Zimbabwe (less than US$ 10 vs US$ 17 per CYP in
            Zimbabwe) sustainability was seen as the biggest challenge
            by the Ministry of Health and Population (MOHP). Lessons
            from this project have already been assimilated by the MOHP
            and are leading to several policy changes. First, the
            ministry is putting greater emphasis on community level
            activities. Secondly, PAC services at the district hospital
            are being provided by Clinical officers and discussions are
            on going to decentralize the services further to the nurse
            or medical assistant at the health center. And finally, the
            MOHP has seen the benefits of working closely with MASAF III.

5081520.trustfund: TF029143-PHRD-POPULATION/FAMILY PLANNING,TF030571-IDA CONSULTANTS POOLED CTF - FY04,TF029142-PHRD-EDUCATION SECTOR III

repnme.cdata!: Malawi - Population and Family Planning Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Population and Family Planning
            Project for Malawi tests the feasibility of a comprehensive
            and district-wide Community-Based Distribution (CBO)
            approach by the government to population/family planning
            services provision in three pilot districts. There are four
            components. The first, community-based distribution,
            recruits community-based distribution agents (CBDAs) to
            distribute contraceptives; provides supervision by CBDA
            supervisors, health centers, family planning coordinators,
            and the district health management team (DHMT); funds an
            incentive package for the CBDAs, plus salaries, motorcycles,
            and motor vehicles; and finances a wide mix of contraceptive
            products. Component 2 supports the development, pre-testing,
            production, and dissemination of information, education, and
            communication materials (IEC); distributes materials in
            local languages on the advantages and safety of family
            planning (FP) and the dangers of STDs/AIDS; modifies
            attitudes towards youth reproductive needs; and provides
            training. Component 3 improves the capacity of health
            professionals to support FP services through clinical
            training; provides clinical supervision to CBDAs; supports
            the FP coordinator; and manages the contraceptive logistics
            system. Component 4 develops standard training protocols for
            service skills, counseling, supervision, and performance
            assessments for CBDAs and their supervisors; trains service
            providers and their supervisors; and disseminates
            educational messages.
